company: Banque Nationale du Canada/National Bank of Canada
headline: A bank looking to play in the big leagues but just not quite there yet.
pros: As with all Canadian banks, great employee benefits (rates, insurances) as well as great vacation packages. If you are in the Montreal area and speak French, lots of opportunities for various careers VS other large banks with head offices in Toronto. The senior bank management (SVP and above) are client oriented, and results driven.
cons:
There are some irritating factors: 
1) Systems are very outdated. It is very apparent National Bank cannot support the same level of investments on its internal systems and applications VS. other large Canadian banks. A lot of tasks are done manually in Excel, pre-populated PDFs and emails, instead of web-based applications, field autofill options, etc. For retail branch banking employees, they are often left to deal with system and operation centers errors, incorrect information entered into client's profiles as a result of manual processes, heavy time-consuming processes to update/subscribe to a product makes it hard for branch people to offer a red-carpet service to their clients. This combined with an unusual number of errors affecting clients, it's very frustrating for branch staff who are client facing and the managers solutions are often to keep the status quo. There is not a lot of focus on first time right and when there is, it almost always rests on the advisor’s shoulders to do or explain the impossible and this affects customer's relationships. 

2) Performance management and compensation are based too much on the manager's opinion of your work instead of your performance figures. Your manager can directly affect your bonus, performance rating and base salary. This shouldn’t feel like a popularity contest but sometimes it feels like you have to please you manager rather than doing what's right or what would be more efficient. Employees, at least in branch banking, are not encouraged to express their ideas to improve processes, nor managers are really opened to hear what you have to say or what kind of experience you can bring to the team. 

3) Diversity - It is a regional bank, in respect to its retail branch banking network, that aims to service clients that are based throughout Quebec mostly. Unfortunately, outside of major city centres (Montreal and Laval), cultural diversity in retail banking is shockingly lacking and this shows in the employee's sentiments towards colleagues coming from other cultural backgrounds and shockingly, clients as well. French is de facto language to use and employees who are bilingual are often reminded that this is a very mostly French-speaking bank and anglophones who don't speak French fluently are not welcomed (be it colleagues or clients). Although corporate is marketing its efforts to cater to a more diverse client profile, branch staff and managers are not making any effort to make it a welcoming environment for these clients and hearing racist comments from colleagues is not acceptable in 2022.

headline: Very poor on-boarding
pros: The benefits like a pension plan and share purchase, the career opportunities, the challenges, opportunities for training and learning new skills and technology.
cons:
Poor or non-existent strategy for on-boarding new employees.  

I was hired as a bank employee in a department that was entirely consultants -- including the team lead.  I was left alone for the first month -- people were too busy to spend time with me.  When there was a crisis, I was not invited to sit in on discussions to begin to absorb the business.  By the end of the second month, I had received a total of 10 hours of knowledge-transfer, training, and general time spent with colleagues.  10 hours over 8 weeks.  I was not involved in any projects.  I was assigned a few tasks after asking for something to do.    

I can understand the consultants reticence in on-boarding a new bank-employee.  It seems like something that should be done by bank employees.  If there are no other bank employees in a department then some other method should be put in place to ensure proper new-hire  integration.

It was clear within two months that I was not welcome nor was I ever going to play a meaningful role in the department.

I could have continued "working" there -- doing nothing for probably months before anyone would have noticed.  That's not a good feeling.

Because the bank is still kind of small in Ontario, general feeling is less structure and control, in compare with other Big 5s. But it is not necessary a bad thing, because each business unit has room to cater to the need and client demographic. If the branch is entrepreneurial, it s can be quite fun and easy to succeed. 
Another thing I like about this bank is the target (objectives) compare to other banks, are significantly smaller, and more achievable.  Overall I find the stress level is not high, and generally speaking the culture is warm and supportive. 
Base salary may look slightly lower than other FIs, but once you get in you will notice the employee benefits are more than generous. Significant low mortgage rate, excellent pension plan etc....
cons:
The operating software and system are very confusing and difficult to learn even for a seasoned banker like me. Sometimes it takes a long time to get one client's request done, or take many steps to finish the administration work. 
Though overall I must say the staff benefits are great, but one thing I am not crazy about is that  new employee need to earn their vacation days for a year before full entitlement kick in. Why not pro-rate the vacation days from the very first year for new employees?
The bank also has several silos, in combination with technology challenge, that can create client experience barrier.  For example, many legacy accounts from the acquisition of Altamira few years ago, or broker referred mortgages, can create more work to the branch than the actual benefit of growing the market via proprietary channel.
